description: Examples for language phrase flashcards - idioms, conversation, formal expressions

examples.title: Formal Salutation - Unknown Recipient
examples.front_question_context: Opening formal letter when recipient unknown
examples.back_answer: Dear Sir or Madam, / Dear Ladies and Gentlemen,
examples.back_explanation: This is the standard formal salutation when the specific recipient is unknown. Used in business correspondence.

examples.title: Thanking in Advance
examples.front_question_text: Vielen Dank im Voraus für Ihre Mühe.
examples.back_answer: Thank you in advance for your effort.
examples.back_explanation: A common and polite phrase to express gratitude for anticipated help or effort. Shows politeness and acknowledgment.

examples.title: In My Opinion
examples.back_explanation: Standard phrase to introduce your personal perspective in conversation. Can be used formally or informally.

examples.title: Better Late Than Never
examples.front_question_hint: About being late vs not at all
examples.back_explanation: A common French idiom meaning it's preferable to do something late rather than not at all. Used to excuse lateness or delay.

examples.title: Expressing Dissatisfaction
examples.back_answer: Unfortunately, I had to realize that...
examples.back_explanation: This phrase is used to introduce a problem or undesirable situation you have encountered, setting a polite but firm tone in complaints.

examples.title: Excuse Me / Sorry
examples.front_question_hint: Formal way to say excuse me
examples.back_explanation: Formal way to apologize or get someone's attention. 'Mi scusa' is informal. Used when addressing strangers or in formal situations.

examples.title: Applying for Position
examples.front_question_text: Hiermit bewerbe ich mich um die Stelle als [Berufsbezeichnung].
examples.back_answer: I hereby apply for the position as [Job Title].
examples.back_explanation: A direct and formal statement for applying to a specific job. Template format allows insertion of specific job title.

examples.title: To Be Over the Moon
examples.front_question_hint: About being very happy or dreamy
examples.back_answer: To be over the moon / To have one's head in the clouds
examples.back_explanation: Spanish idiom meaning to be very happy, excited, or dreamy. Literally translates to 'to be in the clouds'.
